facts.text: On the evening of October 29, 1957, Mr. Bhupendra Narain Singh, Assistant Superintendent of Commercial Taxes, Patna Sadar circle, paid a surprise visit to the shop of Hazari Lall Co., in Barah town to inspect the books of accounts.
Appellant Hazari Lall was in the shop. Mr. Singh found two sets of account books, took them up and started looking into them.
Appellant snatched away both books from Mr. Singh, passed them to one servant who made them over to another servant on the upper floor.
Mr. Singh directed his orderly peon to recover the books. Peon prevented by appellant, scuffle ensued, orderlys shirt torn.
Mr. Singh went to police station to lodge complaint. Appellant brought by Sub-Inspector, tendered written apology, so no complaint lodged.
Mr. Singh submitted written report to Superintendent of Commercial Taxes. Superintendent reported to Deputy Superintendent of Police, FIR lodged on November 1, 1957.
In Criminal Appeal No. 35 of 1961, account book snatched away from Assistant Superintendent was torn in process, part remaining in hands of officer and part with dealer.
Patna High Court upheld appellants conviction under s. 353 IPC and sentence, in judgments dated November 1, 1960 (Cr. Revision 812/1960) and September 1960 (Cr. Revision 76/1959).

legal_issues.text: Whether snatching away account books from hands of inspecting officer amounts to use of force as contemplated by s. 349 IPC and criminal force as per s. 350 IPC, sustaining conviction under s. 353 IPC.
Whether Assistant Superintendent had authority to inspect account books without dealers permission under Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947 s. 17 and r. 50.
Whether officers act constituted seizure requiring reasons in writing under s. 17(3), justifying resistance.
Whether prosecution under s. 353 IPC valid without Commissioners sanction required for offence under s. 26(1)(h) Bihar Sales Tax Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mere snatching away of books does not amount to using force as contemplated by s. 349 IPC and at any rate not criminal force u/s 350 IPC.
No force used against person of Mr. Singh, only to retrieve own property taken without permission.
Act caused no injury, fear or annoyance to Mr. Singh.
Mr. Singh could not inspect without permission, ignoring s. 17 Bihar Sales Tax Act and r. 50.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar Sales Tax Act s. 17, r. 50

petitioner_arguments.text: Officer had seized books without recording reasons u/s 17(3), act illegal, justifying resistance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar Sales Tax Act s. 17(3); Prahlad Ram v. State (Patna HC unreported, Cr. Revision 824/1960)

petitioner_arguments.text: Only offence under s. 26(1)(h) Bihar Sales Tax Act, prosecution invalid without Commissioners previous sanction u/s 26(2). Prosecution under s. 353 IPC colourable to avoid sanction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar Sales Tax Act s. 26(1)(h), 26(2); Sonelal Seth v. State (Patna HC unreported)

respondent_arguments.text: Snatching books caused jerk to officers hand, affecting sense of feeling, amounting to force u/s 349 and criminal force u/s 350 IPC.
Officer authorised for surprise inspection u/s 17(2),(4) and r. 50 Bihar Sales Tax Act, no permission needed.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bihar Sales Tax Act s. 17(2),(4), r. 50

court_reasoning.text: Snatching books caused motion/change of motion/cessation to officers hand and affected sense of feeling, amounts to force u/s 349 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: By snatching away the books which Mr. Singh was holding the appellant necessarily caused a jerk to the hand or hands of Mr. Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Force used intentionally without consent to commit offence or cause annoyance; natural reaction of annoyance to lawful inspection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To feel annoyed at this action of the appellant would be the natural reaction of Mr. Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Officer lawfully entitled to surprise inspection u/s 17(2),(4) Bihar Sales Tax Act and r. 50; no permission needed, obligation on dealer to allow.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mr. Singh was, therefore, lawfully in possession of the account books.

court_reasoning.text: Mere holding books for perusal not seizure (confiscation/forcible taking); distinguishes Prahlad Ram where actual seizure occurred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Seizure implies doing something over and above holding an article in ones hand.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution u/s 353 IPC valid without sanction; graver offence than s. 26(1)(h), prosecution discretion to choose; not colourable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In choosing to prosecute the appellant for a graver offence under the general law the prosecution cannot be regarded as having acted colourably.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Sonelal Seth: overlooked change of motion to person; no need to restrict to s. 26 when general law applies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Had the learned judge home these ingredients in mind he would no doubt have considered the effect of snatching away the books from the hands of the officer.

holdings.text: Snatching account books from inspecting officer amounts to use of criminal force u/ss 349, 350, 353 IPC.
Officer authorised for surprise inspection without permission u/s 17 Bihar Sales Tax Act and r. 50.
Holding books not seizure; no justification for resistance.
Prosecution u/s 353 IPC permissible without sanction even if s. 26(1)(h) also applicable.

precedents_cited.citation: Patna High Court, Cr. Revision No. 824 of 1960, decided October 6, 1960 (unreported)
precedents_cited.relevance: Seizure illegal without reasons u/s 17(3); justified resistance u/s 353 IPC. Distinguished as no actual seizure here.
Snatching not criminal force u/s 353 IPC; prefer s. 26. Distinguished for overlooking change of motion to person.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined force, criminal force; offence of assault to deter public servant from discharge of duty.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of inspection, seizure, entry; obstruction punishable; sanction required for s. 26 prosecution.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; High Court judgment upholding conviction under s. 353 IPC and sentence affirmed. Judgment governs both Criminal Appeals Nos. 35 and 36 of 1961.

key_quotes.text: By snatching away the books which Mr. Singh was holding the appellant necessarily caused a jerk to the hand or hands of Mr. Singh in which he was holding the books.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes use of force u/s 349 IPC.

key_quotes.text: Mere holding books found lying in the premises for perusing them cannot properly be regarded as seizure because seizure implies doing something over and above holding an article in ones hand.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In choosing to prosecute the appellant for a graver offence under the general law the prosecution cannot be regarded as having acted colourably.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Validates prosecution u/s 353 IPC without sanction.
